metadata.name: Tomorrow #172
metadata.description:
Tomorrow is probably the biggest uncertainty of our lives.

We hang absolutely everything on tomorrow, the beginning of a new life, training, studies, hopes, expectations, dreams, and many other things, the list can be very long.

But how often do our expectations come true?

This year I hope everyone understood that you cannot hope and count on tomorrow, there is no tomorrow, there is only today.
Stop putting everything off until tomorrow, you may just not notice how your life flew by and you ended up not doing so much.

The shape of the circle was not chosen by chance, it represents the cyclical nature of our lives and everything we do.
But even in this there are exceptions, expecting that tomorrow everything will go on the same scenario, everything goes exactly the opposite.

15 palettes.
5 formats.
2 different drawing modes.

Press S for Save Canvas as PNG.

By aleks.ustya, @ALEKUSTN. Made with p5js.

metadata.name: Remains #57
metadata.description:
This series explores the remnants and imprints of past events; the unintended consequences and marks left behind: The floor of a painter's studio, layered with splatters and spills; the face of a rock, sculpted by the relentless touch of water and ice; the rusty hood of a forsaken car, weathered and chipped under the harsh sun.

The art piece is crafted by an algorithm simulating the effects of abrasion from a consistent yet dynamic process. It links a thousand pairs of points, harmoniously shifting across the canvas, with delicate lines. At each intersection of these lines, color is applied. To produce the final piece, multiple layers of varying colors and intensities are superimposed.

------

Controls:

- [x] Save a PNG

- [1] Set height to 768
- [2] Set height to 1152 
- [3] Set height to 1536 (default)
- [4] Set height to 2304
- [5] Set height to 3072* 
- [6] Set height to 6144*
- [7] Set height to 9216*
- [8] Set height to 11520*

URL parameters:

- &height={HEIGHT} explicitly sets the render height


* images with height over 3000 pixels render without animating, downloads a PNG automatically after rendering

Please note that high resolution outputs will take several minutes or even longer to render. Highest resolutions have only been successfully tested with Safari on a Mac. If you would like to have assistance in creating high resolution outputs, please contact the author. 


-----

metadata.name: Effluence #83
metadata.description:
“Through our eyes, the universe is perceiving itself. Through our ears, the universe is listening to its harmonies. We are the witnesses through which the universe becomes conscious of its glory, of its magnificence.”

-Alan Wilson Watts


---

Depending on the feature values, this artwork may take several seconds to render.
A modern, capable computer is advised.

To download image at different resolutions, press keys:

1. Low
2. Mid
3. High

---

10 first people minting at auction start price can request high-quality print at no additional cost (DM on Twitter for more details if interested)

Made with p5.js, curiosity and goodwill.

---

Daniel Aguilar
October 2022

Twitter: @protozoo
Instagram: @prtzart
Website: https://protozoo.xyz

metadata.name: Clerestory #249
metadata.description:
Windows welcome daylight, admit fresh air, and offer a view into the outside world. They rarely shatter, always confess the passage of time, and sometimes allow others a chance to look in.

What would the space you're in feel like if it had no windows?

'Clerestory' is an abstract exploration of stained glass windows, drafting shattered sketches for ten potential locations from various perspectives and moments in time. 

Made with WebGL, p5.js, and <3 | CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Collider series - Primitive Expansion #117
metadata.description:
f(hash) = singularity
A glimpse on the primitive expansion of time and space.

500000 particles, pure JS/WebGL/ThreeJS code

Press 'B' to see the primitive expansion animation
Press 'S' to save a 4K PNG of current view (4096x2304)

metadata.name: BWP#4: The Desert #14
metadata.description:
Black and White Patterns: Part Four, The Desert.

The fourth pattern from the black and white series.

This is the generation of the dark, cold desert. The sand slides over the mountains. It is a dark and empty place, there is no life here anymore.

metadata.name: 2fold #21
metadata.description:
My favourite subjects are often simple questions that we ask ourselves since our first teeth. Classics like: before-after, your left or mine, me or not-me, etc

This work, though, is not about binary opposites but about their generators. The sources of the categories that have only two members, both existing solely as the negation or absence of the other. You can face it as heady philosophical stuff or a Sesame Street segment, either way, it's inspiring.

Currently am hopping on the leg that here's no "third actor" in play but actually the two counterparts themselves. The existance of one, immediately spawning the existance of the other, the not-this-one.

When a river spawns its two unmistakeable sides do so too; every place is an inside and an outside; Houses and boxes and teams and eggs.

"Something and anything but" would be a great title but not exactly what I'm exploring here.

This work isn't about explaining -nothing at all- but actually the result of using some common "divisors" as sources for generative outputs.

Using a homemade recipe that mixes equal parts of ballpen scribbles, thin pen lines and, of course, thread, 2fold is my attempt at illustrating these modest but fertile concepts.

Hope you appreciate it. Thanks for staying

metadata.name: Tranquil Orbits #25
metadata.description:
Tranquil Orbits: A Journey Through Calming Vortices, Ethereal Motion, and Meditations in Color

In the vast expanse of darkness, there lies a singular point of gravity, the anchor orb, a celestial body gently cradling smaller orbs in its embrace. The Tranquil Orbits project emerged from a fascination with the subtle dance of these heavenly bodies, bound together by invisible forces, their motions guided by the gentle hand of nature.

The journey of discovery for Tranquil Orbits began as an exploration of the organic nature of celestial movement. An observation of the night sky, with its infinite depth, stirred within a desire to capture the essence of this cosmic ballet. The art project took shape as a series of generative artworks, each a solitary color set against the black canvas of the void.

In this serene landscape, the anchor orb serves as a steadfast guide, providing a sense of stability in the midst of constant change. As the smaller orbs revolve around their celestial guardian, they appear to whisper secrets of the universe, sharing tales of worlds unseen and mysteries untold.

The Tranquil Orbits project is a quiet testament to the beauty of discovery, an invitation to wander through the cosmic expanse, and an ode to the ever-changing dance of celestial bodies. It is not a grandiose proclamation of artistic prowess, but rather a humble exploration of the intimate connection between the observer and the cosmos, where the lines between creation and observation blur and intertwine.

In the end, Tranquil Orbits is not solely about the final product, but rather the process of discovery, the joy of creation, and the subtle dance between order and chaos. It is an invitation to lose oneself in the infinite possibilities of the cosmos and to find solace in the tranquility of the celestial dance.
_____________________________________________

The entire project is developed using Vanilla JS. It features a black canvas and a palette of 24 distinct colors, with one color assigned to each artwork. The artworks exhibit diversity in several aspects, such as the quantity and radii of orbs, the landscape, variations in orb textures, and some rare occurrences like eclipses.

Each artwork is animated using a recursive algorithm, where the large orb gently rotates at its center while the smaller orb(s) revolve around it at varying speeds. Users can control the rotational speed of the smaller orbs and alter their rotation direction. Although each artwork has a predefined position for all orbs, users can pause the animation and save the image in any preferred state.
_____________________________________________

To interact with the artwork:
-	Increase the rotational speed of the smaller orb(s) by pressing 'u'
-	Decrease the rotational speed of the smaller orb(s) by pressing 'd' or to change the direction of rotation. 
-	The animation responds to changes in rotational speed, but it may take a few seconds for the effects to become visible. Please wait for the effect to become visible after you press 'u' or 'd'. 
-	Pause the animation by pressing 'f'
-	Start the animation again by pressing 'b'
-	Capture a 2000 x 2000 image by pressing 'p' (this can be done during both paused and active animation). This will always generate an image with orbs in their current position.
-	Save an SVG file by pressing 's'. This will always generate an image with orbs in minted position.
_____________________________________________

retr0metr0, San Francisco, March 2023. 
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0.

metadata.name: Amplitude #316
metadata.description:
Amplitude is a study in depth. Waves travel across the frame using Perlin noise to guide its modulation. Allowing slight variations to occur in each layer. Sometimes the waves are added to the frame and sometimes they are subtracted. Resulting in dramatically different visual appearances. 

Like most of my work this piece is carefully designed to also exist IRL as a 12 layer laser carved woodcut. 
https://alleditions.art/p/amplitude

Arrow keys - adjust the perspective

DESIGNED FOR IRL
Shift P - for a PNG
Shift E - to explode the layers
Shift S - for an SVG

metadata.name: Smooth-brained #270
metadata.description:
A Generative Art Project by Matthew Hawtin & Murat Atimtay. Smooth-brained is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

The initial visual idea for ‘Smooth-brained’ was to use one pixel and a two-colour gradient in multiple ways across a grid, using repetition, orientation, placement and scale, resulting in a visual composition that became the genesis piece. From that original artwork, Murat took the premise and through creative-coding, began to expand and experiment on the parameters, introducing new visual possibilities and paving the way for this collaborative generative art collection. The beauty of a gradient is that it gives the impression of depth and form on a 2D surface. This allows the visual fields to seem outward and also inward while giving the impression of movement within the whole piece and within individual cells; conjuring up spaces within spaces. The compositions are meant to be spaces for the eye to roam, decorative yet functional, complex yet minimal, a place where the brain is pleased and not duly complicated - a state of ‘smooth-brained’.

Press 1 to 8 export PNG between 1000px to 8000px

metadata.name: Ante Acta #15
metadata.description:
"Ante Acta" was created with p5.js and shaders.

-Press "S" in live view mode to save a .png file in 2K.

Working properly in Chrome, Firefox and Edge.

Creative Credits: https://iquilezles.org/articles/ --- (MIT License).

By Otávio P. Lobato (@AFestinamus), 09/26/2022.

metadata.name: Klyft #608
metadata.description:
“Klyft” is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft’s expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

· URL parameters ·

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> — See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> — See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> — View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true — Save the piece as an image. 

record=true — Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‘Stokkendahl Dalgas’ color scheme:

color=14&record=true

· Interactions ·

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

· Accessibility ·

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS’ VoiceOver, and uses p5.js’ describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don’t hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

· Credits and license ·

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).

metadata.name: Return to Apophenia #27
metadata.description:
Fxhash turns one!
Revenue from initial sales divided 50% 40% 10% between Savepakistan, Processing Foundation and the artist.

Apophenia was my first project on fxhash. It seemed fitting to return to this concept for my anniversary mint and recreate it anew, employing many of the skills I have learned over the last year.

It has some fun interaction...

Mouse click in the centre of a hexagon to rotate that hexagon.
Hexagons have 1,2,3 or 6 unique rotations.

On the keyboard:
'c' to regenerate the work with the colours of the palette rotated
'r' to recreate the work with re-randomised hexagons
't' to change the edge tiles so that the complete image becomes a seamlessly tiling rectangle
'y' to generate a symmetrical image with the same scale and colour palette - this will use different hexagons from the original image and any further interaction will act on the original image, not the symmetrical pattern, which almost certainly won't tile

keys 2 through 9 to render at increasing resolutions

's' to save a .png of the current canvas

26 palettes with random rotations + 12 unique hexagons + 10 hexagon combinations + lots of scale and layout possibilities = virtual infinity

Created with p5.js

metadata.name: Wanderer #251
metadata.description:
Wanderer is an algorithm which uses hexagonal Truchet tiles to produce meandering paths of color. Originally created back in February, I am releasing it as part of this week's #fxhashturnsone celebration.

100% of primary sales will go the the Processing foundation.

Thank you to fx(hash) and to the entire generative art community. 

CONTROLS:

1-9: Increase resolution and save image in PNG format

For third party license information, please see license.md

David Brice Allen
November 2022

metadata.name: Tables #229
metadata.description:
The genesis of this collection are ... good old multiplication tables we all learned back in our days in school. 

There is a pretty interesting way to visualize them : 

Say you take a integer n , ( for example 10 ) and want to represent the table of p ( for example 3 ) for all numbers from 1 to n :
 
You display n dots on a circle labelled from 1 to n
then for each table entry trace a line between dot #i and dot # p x i modulo n 
Example :
1 x 3 = 3 ,  connect n°1 and n°3 
2 x 3 = 6 ,  connect n°2 and n°6 
3 x 3 = 9 ,  connect n°3 and n°9 
4 x 3 = 12 = 10+2 ,  connect n°4 and n°2
5 x 3 = 15 =10+5,  connect n°5 and n°5 
6 x 3 = 18 =10+8,  connect n°6 and n°8 
... 

Play this game with big numbers and you end up with beautiful patterns ...
I took these patterns and twisted them in light & shadow ... 

Made with maths, love and p5.js ... 

Totally responsive , open in live view and play with the browser zoom ...
